Centre for Sustainable Technologies Indian Institute of Science Gulmohar Marg Mathikere Bengaluru 560012 India Graphical abstract Synopsis: In this study, we propose a metal-free co-doping approach to improve CO2 activation and facilitate effective cycloaddition with styrene oxide, thereby fostering solvent-free, mild, and environmentally friendly cyclic carbonate synthesis. This study promotes greener catalytic pathways and advances research on CO2 use by highlighting the synergistic effects of boron and nitrogen in the BN-GCN catalyst. The cycloaddition of CO2 and styrene oxide to produce styrene carbonate under solvent-free conditions offers an eco-friendly, atom-efficient, and highly effective approach to CO2 utilization. This study presents a highly active and selective catalytic system based on boron and nitrogen co-doped graphitic carbon nitride (BN-GCN) for the efficient production of styrene carbonate. Unlike many conventional catalysts, the BN-GCN system operates without needing solvents or metals, functioning as a metal-free heterogeneous catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide. It outperforms other heteroatom-doped graphitic carbon nitride (X-GCN) catalysts, with the enhanced activity attributed to the synergistic interaction of reactants with B and N sites. XPS analysis reveals that the N moiety and the B atom are critical active sites for cooperative catalysis. The BN-GCN catalyst achieves 75 % conversion and > 90% selectivity for styrene carbonate (SC) formation under mild conditions (353 K, 2 bar CO2) within 3 h. Comprehensive material characterization, kinetic studies, and reaction data confirm that B and N co-doping facilitates the co-activation of CO2 and epoxide. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and experiments, a convenient mechanism has been proposed for this unique method. The B–N bond duality in BN-GCN offers a cost-effective, sustainable, and efficient catalytic pathway for CO2 utilization. Keywords CO2 utilization Graphitic carbon nitride Synergistic effects Solvent-free Mild conditions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2, a major contributor to the greenhouse effect, has recently gained significant attention as a sustainable, abundant, and non-toxic feedstock for organic synthesis [1–3]. In response, industry and academia intensified their efforts to leverage CO2 as a valuable raw material for the chemical industries, driving innovation in catalytic processes and green chemistry [4–6]. Consequently, in recent decades, extensive research has focused on CO2 capture through various strategies with N-doped materials and basic metals, demonstrating promising results for effective material development [7]. Drawing from these findings, basic materials, such as amines, alkaline minerals, etc., have emerged as crucial components not only for efficient CO2 capture but also for structural modifications of stable CO2 at key sites [7,8]. Chemists have seized this opportunity to convert activated CO2 at these active sites into valuable chemicals [9,10] including formamides as well as other integrated strategies developed to transform CO2 into high-value products such as methanol, formate, N-formylated formate, and methane (CH4) (Table S1). As a result, the efficient integration of CO2 conversion into high-value chemicals has become a significant area of interest, particularly the conversion of CO2 at the same catalytic system into various products under ambient conditions. This process requires highly reactive secondary reactants, and one promising approach is the reaction of CO2 with epoxides, which has gained considerable attention for the production of cyclic carbonates with 100 % atom efficiency [11]. These cyclic carbonates are increasingly recognized for their emerging applications in electrolytes, solvents, organic intermediates, pharmaceuticals, pesticides, and polymer production [12–14]. A notable example is styrene carbonate (SC), which serves not only as a component of non-aqueous electrolytes in alkali metal and lithium secondary batteries but also as a precursor for various polymers, including aromatic carbamates, thermoplastic polycarbonates, non-isocyanate polyurethanes, and polycarbonate polyols [15–19]. Traditionally, styrene, the key raw material for SC, has been derived from fossil resources [20]. However, recent advancements in sourcing styrene from lignin and plastic waste offer exciting new avenues for research, paving the way for sustainable feedstock conversion into styrene carbonate for next-generation applications [21,22]. The conversion of styrene into SC involves two key steps: the oxidation of styrene-to-styrene oxide (SO), followed by the reaction of SO with CO2 to yield cyclic carbonate. The production of SO is well-established, and its stoichiometric conversion from styrene has been extensively reported [23–26]. In emerging industrial applications, the efficient coupling of CO2 with SO to produce SC is highly desirable. Various catalyst systems, including metal halides [27], metal oxides [28], base-modified zeolites [29], metal complexes [30], ionic liquids [31], have been explored for this transformation (Table S2). Notably, Kim et al. reported highly active imidazolium zinc tetrahalides for the conversion of epoxides to carbonates at 100 °C using 3.5 MPa CO2 [32]. Mechanistic studies indicate that the successful synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides requires both the activation of CO2 on electron-rich sites and the epoxide on electron-deficient sites [33]. To address this, graphitic carbon nitride (GCN) catalysts have been employed for CO2 fixation to produce SC from SO [34]. However, conventional GCN-based materials exhibit limited efficiency due to the presence of predominantly basic sites. To enhance catalytic performance, boron-doped GCN (B-GCN) has been developed, utilizing boron’s electrophilicity to activate epoxides [35]. While these catalysts show promising yields, their efficiency is limited by the need for high temperatures and pressures over extended reaction times (e.g., 24 h). Thus, developing more efficient GCN-based catalysts for green synthesis of cyclic carbonates, especially SC, remains a significant challenge under mild conditions. This work reports a highly active, metal-free catalyst based on boron and nitrogen co-doped graphitic carbon nitride (BN-GCN). This catalyst achieved excellent SC selectivity of up to 90 % under solvent-free conditions at 353 K and 2 bar CO2 pressure. To achieve the co-doping of boron and nitrogen, melamine (Mel) was used as the nitrogen-containing carbon precursor, while boric acid (H3BO3) served as the boron source. The resulting BN-GCN catalyst has dual B-N functionality, balancing electron-rich and electron-deficient sites for effective catalysis. Detailed characterization and mechanistic studies reveal a synergistic interaction between B and N sites, with the catalytic performance primarily governed by primarily pyridine and amine N functionalities. This co-doping strategy not only enhances CO2 activation but also facilitates efficient cycloaddition with SO, paving the way for sustainable cyclic carbonate production under mild, green conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts and reagents Styrene oxide (SO) and tetra-butyl ammonium bromide (TBAB) were procured from Tokyo Chemical Industries (TCI) and Avra Synthesis Pvt. Ltd., respectively. Precursors for BN-doped graphitic carbon nitride (BN-GCN) were sourced from multiple suppliers, including melamine (Mel, Sigma-Aldrich), boric acid (Sisco Research Laboratories), and citric acid monohydrate (Avra Synthesis Pvt. Ltd.). Various epoxides were also obtained from different manufacturers: epichlorohydrin (EC, Sigma-Aldrich), propylene oxide (PO, Spectrochem), 1,2-epoxycyclopentane (ECP, BLD), 1,2-epoxycyclohexane (ECH, TCI), and 1,2-epoxyoctane (EO, BLD). 2.2 Synthesis of B-GCN, N-GCN and BN-GCN B-GCN is synthesized using the procedure reported in the literature with minor modification. 5 g of melamine was dissolved into 60 mL water containing 1.5 g of boric acid. The total solution was evaporated at 353 K till water evaporated to give a white crystalline compound. The resulting compound was calcined at 773 K at a heating rate of 278 K min−1 for 4 h to give a very light-yellow color compound [36]. N-GCN was prepared using 5 g of urea powder and 5 mg of citric acid monohydrate. This mixture was taken in a ceramic crucible and then heated to 823 K at a rate of 275 K min−1 from room temperature in a tubular furnace in air and maintained at this temperature for 4 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained N-GCN was used [37]. BN-GCN was synthesized by the fusion of the above-mentioned standard B-GCN and N-GCN preparation methods [36,37]. In a typical procedure, 10 g of melamine, 10 mg of citric acid monohydrate, and 1 g of boric acid were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water. The mixture was stirred at 313 K for 15 mins and dried overnight at 353 K. The dried material was then transferred to a crucible and calcined at 823 K for 4 h. Various other heteroatom-doped GCNs were also prepared, with detailed procedures provided in the SI. For clarity, the catalysts and their corresponding designations are summarized in Table S3. 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD data of different heteroatom-doped graphitic carbon nitride catalysts were acquired at 30 kV/10 mA using Ni-filtered Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) on a Bruker D8 Advance powder X-ray diffraction. The measurements ranged from 5 to 90° in 2θ angles. 2.3.2 Scanning electron microscope (SEM) A high-resolution scanning electron microscope, the Ultra55 FE-SEM Karl Zeiss EDS, was used for topographical imaging of the catalytic materials. The SEM was operated at 3 kV, using an SE2 detector for imaging. Dried catalytic materials were coated with gold. 2.3.3 Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) The elemental mapping of the materials was determined by Ultra55 FE-SEM Karl Zeiss EDS. 2.3.4 N2 physisorption measurement The specific surface area and pore volume were determined using N2 physisorption and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, employing the BELSORP MAX-2 (Microtrac MRB) operated at liquid N2 temperature (77 K). The BET theory was used to estimate specific surface areas (P/P0 from 0.02 to 1). By using the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model on the adsorption branch of the isotherm, the pore size distributions (PSD) were determined [38]. 2.3.5 Fourier transform (FT-IR) spectroscopy Fourier transform spectra of materials were recorded on a PerkinElmer spectrometer equipped with spectrum software. The FT-IR measurements were performed by taking spectra of samples in a wavenumber range of 4000–500 cm−1. 2.3.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) A monochromatic, micro-focused, low-power (140-watt) al K-Alpha X-ray source was used for X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD (Kratos Analytical Ltd, Manchester England). All the measurements were performed with 300–400 μm X-ray spot size with standard lens mode. The survey spectra were recorded with a pass energy of 160 eV. A high-resolution spectrum of the N1s, C1s, and B1s regions was acquired with 20 eV pass energy. Based on individual elements, the spectra were recorded in the 1200–0 eV range. Subsequent data analysis was conducted utilizing XPSPeak41 software. 2.3.7 Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) TPD measurements were carried out using the Mayura Analytical Temperature-programmed desorption unit to determine the acidic and basic strength of the as-synthesized X-GCN nanosheets. The amount of acidity was estimated by NH3-TPD analysis using ammonia as the probe, while the amount of basicity was estimated by CO2-TPD analysis using carbon dioxide as the probe. The probes NH3 and CO2 were adsorbed at 353 K, over the catalyst surface, and the gas was desorbed at temperatures between 353 K and 823 K. 2.4 Catalytic activity test: synthesis of SC from SO The coupling of CO2 and styrene oxide catalyzed by different heteroatoms doped on GCN (X-GCN) was usually carried out in a 30 mL glass-lined stainless-steel batch reactor with a magnetic stirring bar. The reactor was charged with SO (3.4 mmol), 100 mg of X-GCN catalyst, and 20 mg of TBAB, followed by purging with 2 bar CO2. The reactor was placed in an oil bath pre-heated to an elevated temperature of 353 K, with a stirring rate of 500 rpm. Following the completion of the reaction, the reactor was placed in an ice bath for rapid cooling. Gas chromatography (GC; Agilent GC-8890) with a capillary HP-5 column (30 m x 0.350 mm x 0.25 µm) and dimethyl furan as an internal standard was used to analyze the SO conversion and SC product in the reaction mixture. The formation of products during catalytic reactions was investigated using agaseous GC FID detector. Reactions were carried out in the same manner for all the catalysts as described above. 2.5 Computational details Density Functional Theory (DFT) based calculations were performed using the Gaussian 16 program package [39]. Geometry optimizations of minima and transition states (TSs) were performed using the M06-2X hybrid meta-GGA functional [40] and the 6–31 + G(d) basis set [41]. Normal mode analysis was performed at the same level of theory to confirm the nature of each stationary point. The absence of imaginary frequencies verified minima, whereas the presence of a single imaginary frequency confirmed transition states. The free energies were computed at 298.15 K. The free energy values include zero-point energy and thermal corrections to enthalpy and entropy. All calculations were performedin the gas phase. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of X-GCN in the reaction of CO2 and styrene oxide The coupling of epoxides with CO2 demands an efficient catalytic system. To develop effective catalytic sites, singly doped heteroatoms in GCN (synthesis process detailed in experimental and SI) were explored for converting SO to SC, as summarized in Table 1 . The initial reaction was conducted using pristine GCN, and the result was compared with a blank experiment (Entries 1 and 2). When GCN was tested under conditions of 353 K, 2 bar CO2, and 3 h, it achieved a 41 % yield with 64 % conversion (entry 2). This performance was slightly better than the blank experiment, where tetra-butyl ammonium bromide (TBAB) alone yielded 34 % (entry 1). The catalytic activity observed with TBAB alone can be attributed to the nucleophilicity of the bromide ion, which facilitates the ring opening of epoxides, promoting CO2 addition and carbonate formation. The slight enhancement with GCN is likely due to nitrogen moieties in the material, which help co-activate CO2 on the surface and promote the reaction with the activated epoxide. It is observed from the NH3-TPD analysis that bare GCN possesses lower acidic sites in comparison with its functionalized counterparts, which agrees with the literature (Fig. S1) [35]. Further screening of various heteroatom-doped GCN catalysts revealed a significant improvement in activity, with the SC yield following the trend: N-GCN > B-GCN > O-GCN > P-GCN > S-GCN. The densities of strong acid sites estimated from NH3-TPD measurements on heteroatom-doped GCN follow a similar trend to that of the SC yield (Table 1 & Fig. S1). S-GCN, which has no strong acidic sites, gave a SO conversion of 68 % and a 47 % yield of SC. (entry 3). Despite a high density of weak acid sites, SC yield over P-GCN and O-GCN was lower (entries 4 & 5), which revealed that typical weak acid sites are less active for this reaction at 353 K. The introduction of boron or nitrogen atoms into GCN notably increased the SC yield to 55–60 %, with selectivity ranging between 85–90 %. The NH3-TPD analysis of B-GCN and N-GCN showed two maxima at 723 K and 423 K, ascribable to strong and weak acidic sites. In B-GCN, these acidic sites arise from NH3 adsorption on B atoms with varying chemical environments, while in N-GCN, they result from the incorporation of carboxylic acid (–COOH) groups. According to the TPD results, the total amount of strong acidic sites on B-GCN and N-GCN was determined to be 0.015 and 0.008 mmol g−1, respectively. In contrast, other X-GCN catalysts exhibited lower yields (47–54 %) and selectivity (69–85 %), which had zero to low strong acidic sites. 3.2 Impact of co-doping of B and N on the GCN-catalyzed coupling of CO2 and styrene oxide The catalytic results indicate that boron and nitrogen dopants play crucial roles in enhancing catalytic activity for the coupling of CO2 and SO. Consequently, the co-doping of boron and nitrogen atoms in GCN was further examined. SC yield showed a substantial increase compared to individual B-GCN and N-GCN catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 1 a. The B and N co-doping in GCN was identified as a key feature of the active site. This dual co-doping led to a significant boost in SC yield to 70 %, with an excellent selectivity of 93 %, likely due to the simultaneous activation of SO and CO2. Therefore, these findings differ from previous studies under moderate, eco-friendly reaction conditions (353 K, 2 bar CO2, 3 h). The as-synthesized BN-GCN, B-GCN, and N-GCN catalysts were examined for both acidic and basic sites using NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD analyses (Fig. S2). It was observed that BN-GCN possesses higher strong acidic and basic sites as compared to B-GCN and N-GCN. The NH3-TPD analysis of BN-GCN also showed two prominent maxima at 723 K and 423, attributed to strong and weak acidic sites. The total amount of strong acidic sites in BN-GCN is 0.07mmol g−1, which is very much higher than B-GCN (0.015 mmolg−1) and N-GCN (0.008 mmolg−1). The CO2-TPD analysis of BN-GCN shows two maxima at 773 and 408 K, originating from the strong and weak basic sites. CO2-TPD analysis of B-GCN and N-GCN reveals desorption peaks with maxima at 583 K, indicating the presence of moderate basic sites in both catalysts. These results indicate that the unique catalysis over BN-GCN can be explained by the cooperative action of strong acid sites and basic sites present over BN-GCN (Fig. S2). The catalytic activity across various co-doped GCN samples is shown in Fig. S3, revealing minimal effects when co-doping B-GCN with S or P. Fig. 1 b illustrates the effect of reaction time on the coupling of CO2 and SO catalyzed by the highly efficient BN-GCN catalyst. As the reaction time increased from 1 to 3 h, the SC yield improved from 43–70 %. However, extending the reaction to 4 h resulted in only a marginal increase. The yield of 70 % at 3 h marks the onset of a plateau, indicating that further increases in reaction time have little to no impact on the SC yield in the presence of the BN-GCN catalyst. 3.3 Physicochemical characteristics of different heteroatoms doped GCN We adopted different X-GCN as well-defined model catalysts because of the unique properties of heteroatoms in GCN. This approach enables us to investigate the interaction between heteroatoms and GCN for the coupling of CO2 and SO, as well as understand the impact of various heteroatoms on GCN in this catalytic reaction. The heteroatom-doped carbon materials, which were structurally different, were fully characterized by various characterization techniques. XRD patterns of all catalysts depicted in Fig. S4 show a sharp reflection at a 2θ-angle of 27.5° reported as the (0 0 2) plane, which is attributed to the graphitic structure is equivalent to a d-spacing of 0.49 nm. This is usually ascribed to the distance between the layers of the graphitic material. The peak at 2θ = 13.00° is assigned as the (1 0 0) plane [42]. This is predominant in the case of GCN. Additionally, XRD was employed to investigate the impact of doping in GCN materials. However, all heteroatom-doped GCN still maintain the original crystal structure of GCN after the incorporation of gradient heteroatom layers, as confirmed by the XRD patterns analogous to pure carbon nitride [43–45]. Liu et al. suggested that the doping of nitrogen in N-GCN and BN-GCN involves the addition of citric acid monohydrate over melamine, resulting in two distinct diffraction peaks located at 27.2° and 13°, demonstrating the doping of the carbon matrix with nitrogen [46]. In contrast, there are almost no significant peaks in the XRD patterns of B-GCN since the diffraction peaks are too weak to be observed. Almost all the catalysts have similar d-spacings, around 0.49 nm, confirming the retention of the GCN structure. The bulk structure and morphology of materials were further examined through high-resolution SEM images of heteroatoms doped on GCN catalysts with diverse structures, as illustrated in Fig. 2 and Fig. S5. The typical SEM images of B-GCN reflect a three-dimensional layered arrangement. However, N-GCN and BN-GCN showed a porous sponge-like morphology with a rough surface. Fig. 2 d shows the elemental mapping of BN-GCN, where N and B elements are uniformly distributed throughout the carbon matrix. N2 physisorption measurements were conducted on X-GCN materials (B-GCN, N-GCN, and BN-GCN), each exhibiting unique surface area and porosity characteristics (Table S4). N-GCN displayed a high BET surface area (75.885 m2/g) and pore volume (0.4056 cm3/g), attributed to the increased pore density relative to B-GCN and BN-GCN (Fig. S6). N-doping enhances surface area and porosity through structural modifications to pristine GCN. However, co-doping with B and N reduced the surface area in BN-GCN. BN-GCN materials exhibited a broad pore size distribution with the largest average pore size of 26.848 nm. While no clear correlation was observed between reactivity and surface area, the mesoporous nature and larger average pore size of BN-GCN may improve its capacity to adsorb reactants, thereby enhancing cycloaddition potential. FT-IR spectroscopy was employed to elucidate the characteristics of B, N, and BN-doped GCN materials in Fig. 3 . The tri-s-triazine unit of GCN caused distinctive peaks to appear in all the catalysts at 880 cm−1 [47]. In the meantime, the stretching vibrations of CN and CN heterocyclic compounds, which include both secondary and tertiary amine structures, were reflected in the peaks at 1265 and 1650 cm−1 in accordance with the results demonstrated by Phoon et al [48]. When comparing N-GCN and BN-GCN to B-GCN, the NH stretching is more prominent in the range between 3000 and 3400 cm−1. Li et al determined the B-N vibrations at 1360 cm−1 and 780 cm−1 [49]. BN-GCN generated such characteristic vibrations, which facilitate the interaction of reactants with the catalyst, enabling the ring-opening of epoxide and CO2 activation. These peaks are not prominently visible in the N-GCN and B-GCN FTIR spectra. Peaks at ∼1160 cm−1 suggest the formation of C-B bonds in the catalysts of B-GCN and BN-GCN. XPS measurements of single and co-doped heteroatoms GCN revealed the presence of different kinds of nitrogen, carbon, and boron components in the catalysts. The deconvolution of XPS spectra showed the relative distribution of nitrogen, boron, and carbon ( Fig. 4 ). The deconvoluted XPS spectra of N 1s binding state indicate that N exists in five different chemical environments in the studied N-containing carbons, that is, pyridinic-N (BE = 398.6 eV), amine (BE = 399 eV), pyrrolic-N (BE = 400.2 eV), quaternary nitrogen represented as quat (BE = 402 eV), and N-oxides of pyridinic-N represented as pyr-NO (BE = 403.3 eV) [50]. The high-resolution quantification of the N1s core is clearly illustrated in Table 2 . Abundant N content (28.5 %) in the pyridinic form has been observed in the N-GCN material. However, the active BN-GCN catalytic system demonstrated the substantial presence of N content in pyridine (10.8 %) and amine (9.5 %), followed by quaternary (7.3 %) and pyrrole (7.1 %) forms. The surface content of N remains higher in N-GCN (51 %) and BN-GCN (40 %) samples compared to B-GCN (31 %) due to easier doping resulting from similar atomic sizes, which were ascribed to the high SC yield. The contents of carbon corresponding to the binding energies of C1s are summarised in Table 3 . The central peak at 284.5 eV was attributed to the graphitic C. The 285.5 eV peak is assigned to the combination of aryl carbon double-bonded to N. In contrast, the peaks at 286.15, 287.55, and 288.65 eV are related to carbon atoms attached to different O-moieties in ether/alcohol, ketone, and carboxylic acids, respectively, as demonstrated in Fig. 4 [50]. Quantitative analysis of the XPS data showed 5–10 % of graphitic C in B-GCN, N-GCN, and BN-GCN. For N-GCN and BN-GCN, the CN contribution decreased to 3 % & 2 %, respectively, and B-GCN increased to 6 %. The incorporation of B and N atoms in GCN is concluded to cause the decrease in CN functionalities. CO (≤5 %) and RCOOH (carboxylic acid) (≥7%) groups in all materials were due to the usage of citric acid monohydrate groups, especially in N-GCN and BN-GCN. The relative content of each B-bonding configuration is provided in Table 4 . Fig. 4 g–h depicts XPS fitting, revealing two peaks, 190.8 eV and 189.9 eV, corresponding to C-B-N2 and C2-B-N structures. The peak at around 191.7 eV corresponds to BN3, which can be compared to the trigonal units of boron nitride. Additionally, the presence of BCO2 species is indicated by the peak around 192.8 eV [51]. A quantitative study of the XPS data revealed that 3.9 − 6.68 % boron was present in B-GCN and BN-GCN, respectively. The contribution of C-B-N2 species spiked, but the contribution of C2-B-N groups decreased by the same amount inthe BN-GCN. B-GCN and BN-GCN materials contained B-C species at 3.4 and 1.27 %, respectively, formed by complex synthesis procedures. XPS analysis quantified different types of B coordination, such as B-N-C2, B-C-N2, and BC bonds, for B-GCN, N-GCN, and BN-GCN (Fig. 4 g–h, Table 4). The data revealed a notable increase in the percentage of B atoms in BN-GCN due to additional N doping. However, relative changes in B-N bonding types were minimal, suggesting that the activity relies heavily on the specific type of N bonded to B atoms. Analysis of the B1s XPS spectrum for N-GCN revealed no detectable presence of boron, thereby confirming that boron was not incorporated into the N-GCN structure. Furthermore, when comparing the elemental composition, we observed that the nitrogen content in BN-GCN was notably lower than that in N-GCN. This reduction in nitrogen concentration strongly suggests that boron atoms have been successfully introduced into the BN-GCN framework through the substitution of nitrogen atoms. This observation provides compelling evidence for the effective doping of boron within the material, as the replacement of nitrogen by boron is consistent with the intended modification of the structure of the catalyst. Although XPS analysis investigated the critical role of B and N atoms in facilitating the CO2 reaction with SO to produce SC, it did not provide unambiguous results about which specific nitrogen species are responsible for the catalytic activity. To unveil the active sites rendering the high activity ofBN-GCNtowards the cyclization of styrene oxide, kinetic and mechanistic studies were performed. 3.4 Kinetic studies of SC formation due to cycloaddition reaction To elucidate the mechanism behind the synthesis of SC catalyzed by heteroatom-doped GCN catalysts (B-GCN, N-GCN, and BN-GCN), a comprehensive investigation of reaction kinetics was performed. Reaction rate equations were derived based on reaction rate theory, and initial reaction rates were calculated (Fig. S7). The activation energy was then determined using the Arrhenius equation, with the findings summarized in Table 5 . Activation Energy calculation based on the reaction rates obtained over X-GCN catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 to SO. Reaction conditions: 3.4 mmol of SO; t = 3h; 20 mg of TBAB; 100 mg of catalyst; T = 333–363 K. When the reaction was conducted with only TBAB, the initial reaction rate was 0.0014 mmol/g · s, with an activation energy of 57 kJ/mol—consistent with previous findings for TBAB-catalyzed CO2 cyclization of SO [52]. In comparison, B-GCN, with single-atom doping, showed a slight increase in the initial reaction rate to 0.0019 mmol/g · s compared to the TBAB-catalyzed reaction and a modest reduction in activation energy to 50 kJ/mol. However, using N-GCN as the catalyst substantially increased the reaction rate, nearly doubling it and lowering the activation energy to 44 kJ/mol. Furthermore, B and N co-doping in GCN significantly increased the reaction rate and led to a notable reduction in activation energy to 35 kJ/mol, highlighting that the local environment of active sites affects the transition state structure and energy. Generally, B is electron-deficient, and N is electron-rich, which allows the adsorption of different reactants with electron-rich and electron-poor characteristics. Thus, designing materials with these dual characteristics is essential, as the electron-rich epoxide sites in SO and weakly acidic CO2 benefit from proximity to the catalyst surface for optimal reactivity. Further understanding of the catalyst structure and its active sites responsible for the adsorption of CO2 and SO to perform cycloaddition was studied using DFT calculations. 3.5 Proposed structure and mechanistic studies Drawing from the insights gained regarding the SC yield using different heteroatom-doped GCN catalysts, kinetic studies, and the comparison of active sites using XPS, a proposed catalyst structure is illustrated in Fig. 5 . The following structure was taken considering the charge neutrality and structural integrity during computational modelling, as stated in various literature [53,54]. The catalytic surface of BN-GCN features two distinct regions, T1 and T2, which differ in the chemical environments surrounding the boron atoms (Fig. 5). In both T1 and T2, boron is coordinated to pyrrolic-N (Py-N) and pyridinic-N (P-N) sites (Fig. S8). In addition, T1 is also bonded to quaternary nitrogen (Q-N), while T2 is coordinated with amine-N(A-N). To investigate the effect of different types of nitrogen on the catalytic conversion of styrene oxide (SO) to styrene carbonate (SC) in the presence of CO2, the reactions involving these catalytic centers were scrutinized by DFT-based mechanistic studies and free energy computations. The critical intermediates and the elementary reactions considered in the proposed mechanism (Fig. 6 ) are based on the previous studies on epoxides to cyclic carbonate conversion [55,56]. The relative interaction and adsorption energies mentioned in the following paragraphs are with respect to the free energy of the reactants, R (BN-GCN + Br-SO + CO2 ), unless otherwise specified, and the computed interaction energy profiles are given in Fig. 7 . As can be seen from Fig. 6, the plausible mechanism of SO → SC conversion on the BN-GCN surface involves IM1, IM2, and IM3 intermediates. Here, IM2 is formed by the adsorption of CO2 at different nitrogen sites on IM1, which is formed by the adsorption of brominated SO (Br-SO) at B sites of T1/T2 (Fig. S9). Herein, we analyzed different possible adsorption sequences of Br-SO and CO2. The adsorption energy calculations indicate that the formation of IM1 (IM1-T1 and IM1-T2) by Br-SO adsorption at the B-site is preferred for T1 (−55 kcal mol−1) as compared to T2 (−42 kcal mol−1) by about 13 kcal mol−1 (Fig. 7 and Table S5). We noted that the adsorption of SO on the catalyst surface has higher (more positive) adsorption energies than that of Br-SO (−21 kcal mol−1 for T1 and −20 kcal mol−1 for T2), as indicated by the B-O(SO) bond distance of 2.72 Å (for both T1 and T2), whereas Br-SO was found to be much stronger (B-O(Br-SO) distance of 1.46 Å and 1.48 Å for T1 and T2). Moreover, the CO2 adsorption on BN-GCN was found to be weak, as indicated by the positive values for the adsorption energies (2 kcal mol−1 for T1-IM1′’-Py and 5 kcal mol−1 for T2-IM1′’-A (Fig. S9 and Table S6) in the absence of Br-SO at the B site. This suggests that the adsorption of Br-SO at the B-site form IM1 is the first step of the catalytic cycle, followed by CO2 adsorption at the neighboring N-sites to form the intermediate IM2. The comparison of adsorption energies for the formation of IM2 (IM2-T1-P, IM2-T1-Py, IM2-T1-Q) by the adsorption of CO2 at different nitrogen sites on IM1-T1 suggests that the CO2 adsorption is preferred at the pyridinic N of IM1-T1 as indicated by the substantial decrease in relative interaction energy (−68 kcal mol−1) compared to that at the pyrrolic (−35 kcal mol−1) and quaternary (3 kcal mol−1) nitrogen sites. Similar to IM-T1, CO2 adsorption at the pyridinic nitrogen to form IM2-T2-P (−42 kcal mol−1) was found to be preferred over the adsorption at other nitrogen sites (amine, IM2-T2-A (−39 kcal mol−1) and pyrrolic, IM2-T2-Py (−24 kcal mol−1)) of IM1-T2. Considering the higher relative interaction energies of the IM2 intermediate formed by CO2 adsorption at quaternary nitrogen, further reactions of this intermediate were not studied here. The lower stability of IM2 intermediates compared to IM1 in the cases of IM2-T1-Py, IM2-T1-Q, and IM2-T2-Py can be attributed to the weakening or cleavage of the B-N bond upon CO2 adsorption (Figs. S10, S11 and S13), which could lead to a reduction of aromaticity in the ring system. IM2 intermediates (IM2-T1 and IM2-T2) thus formed and then undergo Br- elimination to form a cyclic intermediate IM3 along the transition state TS1. The interaction energy ( Δ G ‡ ) for this step for different IM2 intermediates are given in Table S7. Comparison of Δ G ‡ indicates that IM2 → IM3 conversion is preferred for IM2-T2 (27 kcal mol−1, 29 kcal mol−1, and 32 kcal mol−1) as compared to IM2-T1 (33 kcal mol−1 and 34 kcal mol−1). Moreover, the Δ G ‡ were found to be comparable for the conversions IM2-T1-P → IM3-T1-P and IM2-T1-Py → IM3-T1-Py (33 and 34 kcal mol−1, respectively), whereas the Δ G ‡ for IM2-T2-Py → IM3-T2-Py (27 kcal mol−1) conversion was found to be lower than IM2-T2-P → IM3-T2-P (29 kcal mol−1) and IM2-T2-A → IM3-T2-A (32 kcal mol−1) conversions. The B-N bond in IM3 was found to be broken for IM3-T1-Py, IM3-T2-Py, and IM3-T2-A, whereas it is intact for IM3-T1-P and IM3-T2-P (Figs. S10, S11, S13–15). IM3 intermediates (IM3-T1-PY, IM3-T1-P, IM3-T2-P, IM3-T2-Py, and IM3-T2-A) then convert to the product, P, along TS2 (Figs. S10, S12, S13–15). In this step, the oxygen atom of the Br-SO moiety coordinated with the B-site attacks the carbon atom of the adsorbed CO2, releasing styrene carbonate (SC) from the catalyst surface. A comparison of Δ G ‡ indicates a lower free energy barrier (36 kcal mol−1) for IM3-T1-Py → P conversion as compared to the steps IM3-T2-A → P (38 kcal mol−1), IM3-T2-P → P (40 kcal mol−1), IM3-T1-P → P (40 kcal mol−1), and IM3-T2-Py → P (43 kcal mol−1 ) (Table S7). Analysis of the free energy profiles (Fig. 7) indicates that the step IM3 → P is the rate-determining step, irrespective of the catalytic centers and the nitrogen sites therein. Further, to get insights into the degree of interaction between CO2, SO, and the catalyst, we calculated the relative interaction energies of different nitrogen sites coordinated to boron, Δ G e f f ‡ (Table S7). Analysis of Δ G e f f ‡ suggests that N-sites on T2 adsorb more efficiently than N-sites on T1. Among the N-sites of T2, amine-N (38 kcal mol−1) was found to have the lowest Δ G e f f ‡ followed by pyridinic-N (40 kcal mol−1) and pyrrolic-N sites. The lowest Δ G e f f ‡ For the reaction at T2-pyridine-N and T2-amine-N centers, the stabilization of the intermediates IM3-T2-Py and IM3-T2-A, respectively, can be ascribed to the more flexible structure due to the elongated B-N bond without affecting the aromaticity and stronger hydrogen bonds in the TS compared to others (Figs. S13 and S15). The highest Δ G e f f ‡ observed for T1-pyrrolic-N can be attributed to the significant destabilization of the intermediates and transition states (IM2-T1-Py, IM3-T1-Py, TS1-T1-Py, and TS2-T1-Py) after CO2 adsorption. The reduction in aromaticity due to the cleavage of the B–N bond and the weak binding of CO2 at the catalytic sites in these intermediates and TS makes them considerably less stable than the intermediate IM1. Thus, the comparison of the Δ G e f f ‡ along the different pathways considered here clearly suggest that the amine and pyridinic N of T2 are the most reactive catalytic sites in BN-GCN for the cycloaddition reaction between SO and CO2. 3.6 Catalyst reusability The recyclability of BN-GCN was systematically evaluated by recovering the catalyst after each reaction cycle through thorough washing with deionized water, followed by drying overnight at 353 K. After the initial use, a slight decrease in catalytic activity and product yield was observed; however, from the second cycle onward, the catalyst demonstrated stable performance with consistent activity and yields in subsequent cycles, as illustrated in Fig. 8 a. This result indicates that while there may be some initial deactivation or loss of active sites observed after the first cycle, the rate of deactivation was lower in successive reuse. Satisfactory recycling of the BN-GCN catalyst was obtained. The catalyst maintains its structural integrity and catalytic efficiency during repeated use, underscoring its potential for practical applications in sustainable catalytic processes. The physicochemical characterization of fresh and used BN-GCN catalysts is given in Fig. S16.XPS and FT-IR analyses reveal that the used BN-GCN loses key nitrogen active sites and structural features, as seen by altered N 1s peaks and weakened BN vibrational bands (Fig. S16 and Fig. 8b). This degradation leads to reduced stability and catalytic performance in the first cycle. Subsequent cycles show consistent catalytic performance and structural integrity. 3.7 Substrate scope Under solvent-free and mild reaction conditions (2 bar CO2, 353 K), various epoxides were employed for CO2 cycloaddition to demonstrate the versatility of the BN-GCN catalyst, as summarized in Table 6 . Aliphatic epoxides such as epichlorohydrin, propylene oxide, and butylene oxides provided excellent yields, ranging from 71 % to 58 % (entries 1, 2, and 3). The difference in activity between allyl glycidyl ether and internal epoxides is ascribed to an electronic effect originating from the electronegativity of the oxygen atom present in the functional group of allyl glycidyl ether, which can enhance the nucleophilic attack by the halide, leading to easier ring opening of this epoxide (entry 4). Notably, BN-GCN efficiently catalyzed the conversion of internal epoxides, such as 1,2-epoxycyclopentane and 1,2-epoxycyclohexane, yielding 47 to 44 % of the corresponding cyclic carbonate (entries 5 and 6). Surprisingly, even inert long-chain alkyl epoxides like 1,2-epoxy octane and 1,2-epoxy decane were successfully converted, achieving good yields of 40–36 % (entries 7 and 8). These results highlight that aryl, cyclic, and long-chain epoxides can be converted into cyclic carbonates under mild reaction conditions (353 K). This suggests that the BN-GCN catalyst offers a subtle, effective interaction with different substrates, facilitating CO2 cycloaddition. The surface of BN-GCN, rich in catalytically active B-N sites, plays a crucial role by simultaneously activating both the epoxide and CO2, driving the cyclization process efficiently. 4 Conclusions In this study, we demonstrated the catalytic efficiency of recyclable BN-GCN catalysts in synthesizing styrene carbonate from CO2 and styrene oxide. Various heteroatom-doped GCN materials were prepared, out of which the co-doped BN-GCN, having a higher amount of strong acidic sites, achieved a remarkable yield with > 90% selectivity in CO2 cycloaddition. This enhanced activity is attributed to the synergistic effect of boron and nitrogen in the B-N active sites, which facilitates the ring opening of epoxides and CO2 insertion. BN-GCN and its unique B-N sites result in efficient CO2 adsorption and activation energy of just 34.5 kJ/mol, signifying that the reaction is kinetically controlled. A series of computational studies was conducted to elucidate the reaction mechanism, revealing that the N-sites on T2 are catalytically more active than those on T1. DFT studies were conducted to learn the detailed reaction mechanism and reveal that the pyridine and amine nitrogen species coordinated to boron have less effective interaction-free energy barriers and play an important role in making the reaction feasible. The BN-GCN catalyst also remains effective for terminal and internal epoxides under eco-friendly, solvent-free conditions at 353 K and 2 bar. This work emphasizes the significance of B-N sites in CO2 fixation and supports the development of more efficient, metal-free heterogeneous catalytic systems for sustainable reactions. coredata.dc:description: The cycloaddition of CO2 and styrene oxide to produce styrene carbonate under solvent-free conditions offers an eco-friendly, atom-efficient, and highly effective approach to CO2 utilization. This study presents a highly active and selective catalytic system based on boron and nitrogen co-doped graphitic carbon nitride (BN-GCN) for the efficient production of styrene carbonate. Unlike many conventional catalysts, the BN-GCN system operates without needing solvents or metals, functioning as a metal-free heterogeneous catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide. It outperforms other heteroatom-doped graphitic carbon nitride (X-GCN) catalysts, with the enhanced activity attributed to the synergistic interaction of reactants with B and N sites. XPS analysis reveals that the N moiety and the B atom are critical active sites for cooperative catalysis. The BN-GCN catalyst achieves 75 % conversion and > 90% selectivity for styrene carbonate (SC) formation under mild conditions (353 K, 2 bar CO2) within 3 h. Comprehensive material characterization, kinetic studies, and reaction data confirm that B and N co-doping facilitates the co-activation of CO2 and epoxide. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and experiments, a convenient mechanism has been proposed for this unique method. The B–N bond duality in BN-GCN offers a cost-effective, sustainable, and efficient catalytic pathway for CO2 utilization.
coredata.dc:title: Unraveling B, N Co-doping synergy in graphitic carbon nitride for efficient CO2 cycloaddition with styrene oxide
